text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Shu Shu
album Nina any month you get to talk
about Nina Simone twice on your music
review vlog is a good one
jazz singer pianist and songwriter Nina
Simone has been getting a lot of
attention over the past half a year so
mostly because of a sample of one of her
songs that landed in one of the bigger
tracks of Kanye West's latest LP yeezus
however my favorite tribute to her music
from this past year comes in the form of
this record from artpop experimental
rock outfit Shu Shu with
singer-songwriter and frontman Jamie
Stewart masterminding the whole thing
this project has been putting out LPS
for about 10 years now and in my opinion
Nina ranks as one of those projects most
ambitious albums yet it features eleven
revisions of songs that Nina had either
written or just had a really great
performances of in her discography and
even though there are tribute albums out
there already for Nina Simone's music
and there are a lot of tribute albums
out there in general I would like to
think of this record as a big deal I
would like to think of it as a big
undertaking for Shu Shu I think the band
has shown no lack of ambition with a ton
of raw live instrumentation on this
record backed with horns which brings a
bit of a human element into the equation
which has been sort of missing from some
of the more glitchy and electronically
driven albums they've been putting out
recently however even with the effort
being put into getting this live
instrumentation putting the Arrangements
together Shu Shu has come out with a
covers album that is so stylistically
and just sonically off the mark I'm not
really sure I could responsibly
recommend it to nina simone fans and
it's it's not really because this record
isn't jazzy enough if there's anything
proven by the end of this LP it's that
Jamie Stewart and the musicians he works
with on this LP have a very firm grasp
of jazz instrumentation what's probably
going to be an issue is that even though
this thing is a Nina Simone covers album
it sounds a lot more like the last Scott
Walker album a lot of the instrumental
arrangements throughout these tracks are
noisy they're dissonant they're
cluttered and Jamie Stewart singing on
these songs is more unorthodox than
usual for a shoo-shoo album whisper
quiet very breathy hanging mostly in the
lower register and it also sounds like
throughout these tracks that steward is
in some kind of great amount of pain
most likely emotional but I wouldn't
rule out physical what disappointed me a
little at first is that Jamie's vocals
are a little quiet and a little whispery
a little understated considering that he
is trying to tribute one of the best
voices in jazz he's trying to tribute a
jazz great however what he does do
singing in the fashion that he does on
this record is captures the inherent
eeriness and a lot of these Simone songs
making them way more twisted and
nightmarish especially on tracks like
pirate Jenny where Jamie Stewart sort of
takes some lyrical liberties in a story
about a woman who is working on a ship
and is planning to sneakily kill all the
passengers when they least suspect it
and Jamie delivers this song like an
evil villain sort of unfolding his plan
to a single listener in secret it's a
great track it's one of my favorites
it's a song where I actually think the
odd vocal styling plays really well into
the lyrics of this Nina Simone song
however there are some tracks here that
I think maybe are a little too spooky
for their own good that spookiness that
comes with the sparse instrumentation
and Jamie's vocals over takes some of
the melody or maybe what the storyline
is a lot like on the opening track here
don't smoke in bed the horns on this
track do a fantastic job of very
quaintly adapting the opening melody but
I feel like the singing on this song
with it being at its most whispery on
this entire record possibly doesn't
really do the tale here justice I mean
what this song is lyrically is really a
lot like a letter that you find in the
kitchen one morning when you wake up to
see that your significant other has
completely disappeared and they're
leaving you however with the vocals
being so eccentric on this record and
this track and and so theatrical it
forces me to kind of imagine why they
would be sung in this way and the only
scenario where that I could come up with
is that this
person is trying to slink away and say
their final goodbyes without waking
their significant other up but really I
can only guess why certain things happen
and why certain things sound the way
they do on this record outside of the
moments where melodies and
instrumentation very clearly mimics
spots from these original Nina Simone
tracks there isn't much on this record
that makes clear obvious sense the song
where can I go without you for example
one of my favorites on here but still a
song with these very sparse Celeste
melodies and sort of funhouse sound
effects creaking and just causing a riot
in the background against Jamie Stewart
it's just soft quivering voice this song
sounds like something you would hear
walking down the hallway of and saying
asylum in the middle of the night and
you sort of peek into a padded room and
see some straitjacket sweaty guys
singing this song to himself rocking in
a corner a lot of the decisions made in
adapting these tracks seem more personal
than practical and sometimes Shu Shu
pushes the envelope so far that some
people may think that these tracks are
just too overacted they're too freaky to
be genuine or enjoyable and I think that
would be the case if you were just
simply holding this record to a rock or
a pop music standard and even though
those genres do inform many of Shu shus
records I think this is one of the few
LPS that they've put out where that just
does not cross over here Nina scratches
a whole series of different itches this
is a record for people who like their
music to be very eccentric dissonant
challenging odd and chaotic if that's
the case there's no reason that a track
on here like while does the wind
shouldn't appeal to you I love the
tension in this track the rickety
percussion just causing a riot in the
background
the duet horns and the guitar all sort
of moving at the strange fluid pace just
a cloud of instrumentation orbiting
Jamie's dying breath vocals the south
and what's incredibly haunting on this
LP is the very steady pace of the track
don't explain the music sounds like the
soundtrack to someone slow painful
murder with Jamie Stewart sounding like
he has tears rolling down his face as
he's singing the song there are some
moments on this LP though that are very
visceral like the song sea lion woman
which has some very hard-hitting
percussion in the background wild horns
with some wailing screaming free jazz
embellishments and Jamie Stewart's
vocals are just hot intense they're loud
reaching into his upper register I wish
we saw this side of his voice more and
even though this track is in a way a
highlight because of how loud it is it
does not really make it into my
favorites on here because it's a little
short of breath on the length still the
song for women is another very loud and
intense track and is a bit longer pays
off with a really awesome chord
progression at the finish with the horns
resolving in a really beautiful way and
the song you'd be so nice as well I feel
like pushes that free jazz
experimentation even further with the
horns going absolutely nuts and behind
all of it there's this really strong
jazz walking bass line it feels like
some sort of freaky perversion of a
track from the Twin Peaks soundtrack so
there are aggressive moments on this LP
there are just freaky eccentric moments
on this LP they're sad spots here
they're creepy spots here but there are
moments here that I do think are
hauntingly beautiful are sort of soulful
as well like the opening horn melodies
on the track just say I love him which
also features some very beautiful
accompaniment throughout from guitar and
a bit of melodica as well as they bounce
back and forth with the vocals just as
this LP is great at churning out sounds
that are hugely disturbing it's just as
good as putting out sounds that are
moving even after 40 minutes the
acoustic guitar backed song the other
woman sounds kind of rude Sein and
friendly in comparison with the other
tracks here even though this song as
well is fronted by Jamie Stuart's very
strange vocal stylings I will say the
only downside to this track is while I
do like the thought of what they tried
to do with
tender side of this song in this record
I do think Jamie Stewart's singing style
here does sound much better with heavier
accompaniment overall I have to say this
LP is really unique in my opinion it's
entertaining it's strangely fun and
bizarre and with how eccentric this
record is especially in the vocal
Department I do realize that this album
is gonna garner some really strong
opinions people who are just far into
hating it and people who are far into
loving it and those opinions might even
swing further into the hating it
direction simply because this thing is a
Nina Simone covers album and these
covers aren't exactly complimentary in a
really obvious way but to me after
numerous listens to this album it's very
apparent that Shu Shu deeply appreciates
and understands the emotions and the
stories that are laced into every Nina
Simone song at least the ones that they
covered here as well as the instrumental
quality - and the way that the band goes
about covering these songs is so
incredibly interesting as well just
taking single ideas instrumentally just
sounds or chord progressions or tones
and just exaggerating them or magnifying
them to the point where it feels like an
entirely different song and once you've
magnified this one single piece and just
brought it out and just made it bolder
and weirded it up a little bit then the
entire song around this is sort of free
for you to recreate Shu Shu takes a ton
of liberties with these nina simone
songs there's no denying that but
despite that I do think that there is a
ton of power and and beauty to this
record I'm feeling a light eight on this
album transition if you've given this
album a listen and what do you think I
should review next let me know yep any
Fantana
Shu Shu Nina Simone forever
